projects.title: Master thesis on the Governance of Climate Adaptation: Defining governance arrangements to steer effective flash flood adaptation in Arnhem.
projects.description: Climate change results in increasing urban heat stress and growing risk of pluvial and fluvial floods in Dutch cities. Multiple researchers have shown that several types of barriers hamper the adaptation to these growing risks. Climate adaptation governance has shown to stimulate the implementation of adaptation strategies and help overcome these barriers to adaptation. Despite a growing body of literature on adaptation governance, knowledge on local climate adaptation governance remains limited. This thesis adds to the understanding of local climate adaptation governance. A conceptual framework which integrates climate adaptation, adaptive capacity, governance and institutionalism, is used in a case study research to analyze flash flood adaptation governance processes in Arnhem. The preliminary focus of the case study is on the interrelationships between municipality, residents, housing associations and insurers. Governance is used as both a descriptive and normative tool to give insight in the complexity of local adaptation governance processes and to formulate governance arrangements to steer effective flash flood adaptation. The concluding section reflects on how adaptive capacity, institutionalism and governance context influences local flash flood adaptation governance processes in Arnhem and reveals five adaptation governance bottlenecks. Subsequently, seven governance arrangements are formulated to help steering effective adaptation to flash flood risk in Arnhem.

projects.title: Meerwaardecreatie in Nederlandse infrastructuurplanning: op zoek naar belemmerende en stimulerende factoren.
projects.description: In dit onderzoek ligt de nadruk op het proces van meerwaardecreatie in integrale infrastructuurprojecten. Meerwaardecreatie is een begrip dat centraal staat binnen het nieuwe tijdperk van uitnodigingsplanologie. Uitnodigingsplanologie wordt wegens organisatorische en financiële knelpunten binnen gebiedsontwikkeling veelvuldig erkend als de volgende stap die nodig is binnen Nederlandse ruimtelijke ordening. Echter blijkt zowel in de literatuur als in de markt nog veel onduidelijkheid te bestaan over de precieze inhoud en het proces van meerwaardecreatie. In dit onderzoek wordt getracht inhoud te geven aan het begrip meerwaardecreatie aan de hand van vier principes. Deze principes worden vervolgens gekoppeld aan een conceptueel model wat wordt ingezet om het proces van meerwaardecreatie binnen twee natte infrastructuurprojecten (A2 Maastricht en de zuidelijke ringweg Groningen) en twee droge infrastructuurprojecten (Huissensche waarden en de Avelingen uiterwaarden Gorinchem) te ontleden. Gebaseerd op empirisch onderzoek worden concrete stimulerende en beperkende factoren voor meerwaardecreatie aangewezen.

projects.title: The Lower Weser, Towards a flood resilient region; a case study on Bremen and the Lower Weser area.
projects.description:
https://prezi.com/5i09vukayva9/prezi-on-lower-weser-area-towards-a-flood-resilient-region/

The past decades  Europe has seen an increase in the frequency and severity of flood events. Due to climate change the risk of flooding is very likely to increase in the future. In the winter of 2013 storm Xaver showed that this threat is also pertinent for the Lower Weser area in Germany. Although the system proved capable of resisting the storm, water levels reached  the third highest level since 1907. This research is assessing the resilience of Bremen and the Lower Weser Area to flooding. This is done by using a methodological tool called 'the wheel of resilience' which has been specially constructed for this study. The wheel of resilience scores multiple criteria that determine the  robustness of a system before a flood, the adaptability of a system during a flood and the transformability of a system after a flood. The result will be a  clear indication of the resilience of the study area. The results are presented in a communicative figure which straightforwardly shows the strong and weak segments of the systems’ resilience.    This figure can be used to enhance the  resilience of Bremen and the Lower Weser area in the face of growing flood risk.

projects.title: Participation is key to Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM).
projects.description:
https://prezi.com/0hlnwsjxr-qf/particpation-is-key/

The coastal zone is of great environmental, economic, social, cultural and recreational importance to Europe. The increasingly deteriorated state of the European coast and depletion of the limited resources is leading to increasingly frequent conflicts between these different uses.  Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) is a widely implemented approach which aims at dealing with the complex reality of these coastal areas. This paper focuses on the  interpretation of ICZM by the European Commission and formulates a response to the statement: “participation is key ICZM”.  This is done by first defining participation, then  defining ICZM and finally elaborating on participation in ICZM. This paper is based on literature research.  The results confirm that participation is indeed key to ICZM.

projects.title: Flood (risk) management policy, a comparative research between Bremen and the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames.
projects.description: The 2007 EU Flood directive, defines flood risk management as the new norm for creating flood policies.  Member states are required to prepare flood risks management plans for all river basins and associated coastal areas before December 22nd 2015. For some countries that will be easier than for others. This cross-national comparative research between Kingston and Bremen analyses two types of regional flood management approaches.  The goals of this research are first, to explain why Bremen still practices flood control management while Kingston has successfully switched to flood risk management. And second, to determine, learning from the Kingston situation, how a transition to flood risk management can be encouraged in Bremen. This is done by comparing national policy styles, institutional structures and flood management policies of the two cases. Failure of the flood control approach, difference in policy styles and variation in juridical framework are pointed out as arguments why the approaches differ between the two cases. Subsequently concluding that failure of the current approach, change in policy style or altering juridical principles could encourage the transition from flood control management to flood risk management  in Bremen.

projects.title: Multifunctionality in retention areas in Northwest Europe
projects.description: To deal with the growing risk of fluvial floods, creation of retention areas has gained much popularity in Northwest Europe. The temporal use of retention areas for water storage generates opportunities for multifunctionality. After discussing to the origin and meaning of the concept multifunctionality, the significance of retention areas and the value of multifunctionality in retention is substantiated. Subsequently this paper elaborates upon four function combinations which are possible in retention areas; nature development, agriculture, recreation and mineral extraction.
